question: William of Orange was asked by Protestants to invade England and proclaim himself king. But, when William reached England, there was no resistance and he took over the throne. This event was later Known as:
After the Act of Union was agreed upon in 1707, Scotland
options: was no longer an independent country

question: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports known as:
People in the UK have to pay tax on their income, which includes:
options: Income from property, savings and dividends

question: Which court deals usually with divorce cases in Scotland?
The burial place of one of the kings was at Sutton Hoo in modern Suffolk
tip: The burial place of one of the Anglo-Saxon kings was at Sutton Hoo in modern Suffolk. This king was buried with treasure and armour, all placed in a ship which was then covered by a mound of earth.

question: In which years did British Film Studios flourish?
tip: British studios flourished in the 1930s. The 1950s and 1960s were a high point for British comedies, including Passport to Pimlico, The Ladykillers and, later, the Carry On films.

question: The Assembly has the power to make laws for Wales in ______ areas
Satirical magazines began to be published in the 19th century. When was 'Punch' first published?
tip: Punch' was published for the first time in the 1840s

question: In which year was the first Union Flag created?
tip: The Welsh dragon does not appear on the Union Flag because, when the first Union Flag was created in 1606 from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already united with England.

question: By which of these is The Queen referred to, in the first verse of the anthem?
tip: The first verse is:'God save our gracious Queen!Long live our noble Queen!God save the Queen!Send her victorious,Happy and glorious,Long to reign over us,God save the Queen!'

question: Who invented Insulin?
tip: The Scottish physician and researcher John MacLeod (1876–1935) was the co-discoverer of insulin, used to treat diabetes.

question: It is compulsory to join National Citizen Service programme for 16 and 17 year olds.
tip: There are many opportunities for young people to volunteer and receive accreditation which will help them to develop their skills. These include the National Citizen Service programme, which gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

question: In 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 18, the same age as men.
tip: The voting franchise was also extended to women over 30, and then in 1928 to men and women over 21. In 1969, the voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.

question: When did Britain became permanently separate from the continent by the Channel?
When did the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms establish in Britain?
tip: Britain was invaded by tribes from northern Europe: the Jutes, the Angles and the Saxons. The languages they spoke are the basis of modern-day English. Battles were fought against these invaders but, by about AD 600, Anglo-Saxon kingdoms were established in Britain.

question: What is the traditional Christmas meal?
options: Fish and chips, followed by tea
Roast turkey and pudding made from suet, dried fruit and spices
Oatmeal with blueberries and apple pudding

question: Regarding to the myth When does father Christmas comes?
Where can you get help from if you are facing domestic violence?
tip: It is important for anyone facing domestic violence to get help as soon as possible. A solicitor or the Citizens Advice Bureau can explain the available options.

question: There are ______ members of the Scottish Parliament (MSPs)
The second-largest party in the House of Commons is called the opposition.
tip: The second-largest party in the House of Commons is called the opposition.

question: The Patron Saints' days are NOT public holidays in which TWO countries?
tip: Only Scotland and Northern Ireland have their Patron Saint's day as an official holiday. While the Patron Saints' days are no longer public holidays in England and Wales, they are still celebrated. Parades and small festivals are held all over the two countries.

question: The Blitz is associated which event?
options: The UK and Germany bombing French cities
The UK evacuating troops from Dunkirk
tip: Despite winning the Battle of Britain, the German air force was able to continue bombing London and other British cities at night-time. This was called the Blitz.

question: David Hockney was an important contributor to the ‘pop art’ movement of the 1960s
tip: David Hockney (1937–) was an important contributor to the ‘pop art’ movement of the 1960s and continues to be influential today.

question: Charities that work for the homeless are
St David is the patron saint of which country of the UK?
tip: St David is the patron saint of Wales, and St David's Day is celebrated on 1 March each year.

question: When did the Industrial Revolution take place?
tip: The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries.

question: What percentage of the total population lives in Scotland?
tip: The population is very unequally distributed over the four parts of the UK. England more or less consistently makes up 84% of the total population, Wales around 5%, Scotland just over 8% and Northern Ireland less than 3%.

question: Scotland and Northern Ireland have their own banknotes
tip: and its valid everywhere in the UK

question: Dunkirk is associated with the events of
options: Small boats coming to the rescue

question: The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries.
tip: The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries.

question: The Head of the State and the monarch in both ceremonial and symbolic sense is
When did people learned to make bronze?
What is Boxing Day?(Choose TWO)
tip: Boxing Day is the day after Christmas Day and is a public holiday.

question: Anne Boleyn the wife of Henry VIII was accused of taking lovers so she was executed at
What festival is celebrated on 31 October in the UK?
Which Scottish king defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn in 1314?
tip: The English were defeated at the Battle of Bannockburn by Robert the Bruce in 1314.

question: What country did Hitler invade in 1939?
tip: The British government tried to avoid another war. However, when Hitler invaded Poland in 1939, Britain and France declared war in order to stop his aggression.

question: In Northern Ireland, what letter does a newly qualified driver has to display for one year after passing the test?
tip: In Northern Ireland, a newly qualified driver must display an ‘R’ place (for restricted driver) for one year after passing the test.

question: In what county can you see a hill fort at Maiden Castle?
tip: A very impressive hill fort can still be seen today at Maiden Castle, in the English county of Dorset.

question: What is the second biggest country in the UK?
tip: Scotland has the second highest population and area.

question: William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690. This event is celebrated in which country?
tip: William defeated James II at the Battle of the Boyne in Ireland in 1690, an event which is still celebrated by some in Northern Ireland today. William re-conquered Ireland and James fled back to France.

question: The main Olympic site for the 2012 Games was in ______
When William of Orange re-conquered Ireland (in 1690) he took the title ‘William the Conqueror’
tip: In 1066, an invasion led by William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. Harold was killed in the battle. William became king of England and is known as William the Conqueror.

question: Who has to pay National Insurance Contributions?
options: Everybody in the UK who is in paid work
tip: Almost everyone in paid work, including the self-employed, have to pay National Insurance Contributions (NICs). The contributions help pay for state benefits and services such as the state retirement pension and the National Health Service (NHS).

question: Which sport can be traced back to the 15th century Scotland?
tip: The modern game of golf can be traced back to 15th century Scotland.

question: The currency of Northern Ireland is also valid in other parts of the UK.
tip: Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes, which are valid everywhere in the UK. However, shops and businesses do not have to accept them.

question: When were the first coins in Britain made?
What must you buy if you have a device that can be used for watching or recording TV programmes?
In the UK many people speak Welsh, Scottish Gaelic and Irish Gaelic.
tip: There are many variations in language in the different parts of the UK. The English language has many accents and dialects. In Wales, many people speak Welsh – a completely different language from English – and it is taught in schools and universities. In Scotland, Gaelic (again, a different language) is spoken in some parts of the Highlands and Islands, and in Northern Ireland some people speak Irish Gaelic.
